												Edit: Protip #1 - Bunny hop. Protip #2 - RAVE GUNThis just kicked my nostalgia into overdrive. The teams at Big Boat and Rebellion have done a grand job bringing the shine back to this gem from the late 90s. The new lighting and particle effects, as well as high-poly models and hi-res retextures bring the magic back to the current generation.After the first samples of a mysterious material known as 'bio-metal' fell to Earth in 1952, the two major superpowers facing off in the cold war - the USA and the USSR - utilised it to construct amazing new prototype vehicles and weaponry. Ever seeking greater sources of power, this whole new world of technology spawned from the stars spurred on humanity's thirst for the untapped resources of deep space...One of the early [and sorely missed] action-strategy hybrid titles, Battlezone's first campaign casts you into a conspiratorial wing of the United States military - the National Space Defence Force (NSDF) - which is expanding out into the solar system during the cold war. The USA has used the smokescreen of the highly publicised Space Race to deploy a division of their military forces on the moon. What is this strange, otherworldly bio-metal scrap? Can such a malleable and strong substance really form naturally? All that truly matters at the outset is keeping it out of Russki hands at all costs...In the second campaign, you play from the perspective of a Russian cosmonaut on the other side of the conflict. The differing design philosophies of the two factions is striking. The Soviet Cosmos Colonist Army (CCA) favours brutal head-on attacks and overwhelming numbers. Beginning with much the same immediate goals in mind as the USA (though initially more intrepid and bold in their conquest), the USSR expand rapidly to the Red Planet. Of course, not all is as it seems, and the cosmonauts quickly find themselves wishing they were safely home in the Motherland's bosom, for the cold of space is not inviting, and grander things lurk just out of sight...--A great piece of alternate history fiction with excellent gameplay values. You can jump in and out of any given hover-vehicle to wander around on the surface of many planets and moons around Sol. With your trusty sniper rifle, you can whack hostile pilots from a distance and jack their ride, if you so choose. The combat is frenetic and satisfying, driven by the desire for ultimate control over these new resources. Perhaps the most gratifying element of this game is the fluidity of its movement. The jet-thruster-powered movement of most of the vehicles allows for some spectacular handling of rough terrain, cruising along at high speed and ramping off outcroppings of rock, lending the game abundant z-play opportunities. Moving effectively and working as a team is absolutely as crucial as landing hits on target.In many missions (as well as the instant-action and multiplayer[!!!]), designing, constructing and managing your base falls to you. The bio-metal is extremely versatile and can be used in conjunction with a Recycler vehicle to construct all manner of buildings, vehicles and bizzare, devastating weaponry, ranging from tanks and mobile turrets to howitzers, rocket platforms and walkers. You will need to protect your scavengers, deploy your battle lines and make offensive strikes on enemy positions, all the while keeping track of the number of pilots you have at your disposal, and that ever-crucial supply of bio-metal scrap. You can manage every unit in your force, every building and utility vehicle under your command, from anywhere on the very sizeable maps using the fairly intuitive command interface.Strategy and tactics evolve organically lending the gameplay as much or as little head-on action as you please, requiring you to source scrap fields and expand your production line and deny those same resources to your enemy. Your co-pilots are as effective in combat as you are, and you'll need all the help you can get throughout the challenging campaign.Pick this up, it's probably quite unlike anything else you'll play this year, and you won't regret it.

												Battlezone has always had a special place in my heart since I first piloted a Grizzly tank, on Mars, with an army at my back, facing an enemy just as powerful as I was. The concept is flawless- a masterful FPS and an intuitive RTS cleanly blended together in a hovertank space shooter. Remastering this timeless classic is one of the greatest revitalizations I've come across.The game offers a unique environment where standardized FPS elements are challenged and redefined. I am a huge fan of ammo shared between all of your weapons. Combined with the mobile, dynamic RTS that forces you to make decisions based on the type of terrain you're in and what the enemy is building, just like any RTS. However, the only thing I find lacking in the entire game is the RTS itself as I personally find it quite simplified, but in exchange for the complexity of strategy there is a first-person combat experience to steal the focus from.As a modder for the original game from 1998, I am enthusiastic about the capabilities the Redux has, especially Steam Workshop support. The unified and proven system Workshop offers will give my creations more exposure than ever before, something I look forward to and intend to make the best of.The game has survived eighteen years of existence. Some said Battlezone was "the best game you've never played". With the Redux, that will change. Battlezone is better than ever before, and it is destined to bring both old and new players back to the front lines.- blue banana

												This is the best game you've never played. It's the hidden gem of hidden gems.Set in an alternate 1960s where the space race is just a cover for a cold war turned hot, the United States and Soviet Union secretly deploy massive armies into space in pursuit of an extra-terrestrial substance, bio-metal, that can be used to craft amazing and powerful weapons of war. The National Space Defense Force (NSDF) and Cosmos Colonist Army (CCA) do battle over control of the bio-metal throughout the solar system using hover tanks crafted from the precious material. Battlezone has some of the best sci-fi lore of any game- don't skip over the briefings and debriefings! Battlezone has always had interesting gameplay because of the way it blends RTS and FPS elements. You primarily play the game from the view of the cockpit of your hover tank: you can hunt down enemy craft yourself and blow them away, OR, you can deploy your recycler (main production unit) at a nearby geyser power source and being collecting bio-metal using scavengers in order to build a base, defensive structures, and wingmen to take into battle with you. If you build a Comm Tower, you can take a satellite view of the battlefieldzone and command your wingmen in traditional RTS style, but you don't need to have a Comm Tower to effectively command all of your units (in fact, most often it is better to NOT take this approach).Battlezone 98 Redux (BZR) has received many improvements over the original game. These include highly improved terrain textures, models, lighting, menus, and more, and these alone make the game worth a purchase and play through. However, because BZR is built on the code of the 1998 release, some of the baggage from years ago has made its way into this game. The net code, though improved, still struggles from time to time, and having a good connection can be important to having an enjoyable online experience. (Overall this is has never been a problem for me, though.) The sound system also struggles mightily when there are many units in play or in a battle- it will eventually just choke and cut out completely until there are fewer units. The sound cutting out is a scenario that you're for the most part unlikely to encounter during regular gameplay, however.Keeping these small qualms in mind, the game is absolutely a steal at its current price, and will buy you hours and hours of fun in space. I SAID FUN IN SPACE!If any 90's game deserved a Redux, this was it. Especially if you never played the original (but even if you have!), this is a must buy.10 Grizzlies out of 10.

												Let's think about this for a moment here.The story involves The Cold War cover up where the actual battles took place all over space. Space tank space race. The gameplay is an incredibly well thought out combination of a squad based fps shooter with command and conquer-esque rts elements which has only been done just a few times, none of which has come close to Battlezone in execution.Because let's face it, there is no reason to attempt it again. It was done perfectly the first time and all future attempts will fall short of greatness.The base building is satisfying as you go from a small recycler to a full-on citadel of gun turrets and mines as you balance a need to finish off the mission as well as keeping your scrap intake moderated so you do not inadvertantly starve yourself of resources. That's where the first-person squad based gameplay comes in. There are a wide variety of different tanks to choose from with a varying degree of playstyles between them, starting from a nimble and weak Scout/Fighter to a slow, powerful Walker/Golem. Bread and butter Tanks to niche fillers such as Rocket Tanks and Bombers to tackle specific situations that may arise as you fight over a planet. No one tank feels completely useless and all feel as if they can be useful in a one-on-one fight if used/maneuvered correctly. If you choose that the fps gameplay isn't exactly your sort of thing, there exists more traditional RTS elements through satellites that give an overhead view of a map where you can micromanage your tanks effectively rather than blow things up yourself.It is legitimately my favorite game, and now it has an HD remake and runs perfectly on a modern PC.This game and all it offers deserves a playthrough, because it never got a fair shake when it initially came out. Think about it for a moment, Atari released boatloads of reboots of their old franchises and most of them were terrible because it did not do anything remotely interesting. Along comes another old arcade reboot which served as the antithesis of everything Atari was churning out. It not only features the badass story that hooks you on its sheer craziness, the gameplay has also aged incredibly well.Infinite recommends, you should play this and experience one of the most unique games to come out of the 90s. As jaded as I've become over video games along comes this one title I fawned over as a child which shows me that yeah, video games are still pretty great, and Battlezone is just as unique and entertaining as the day it came out. Battlezone revealed to me that I love video games, and it deserves to be your favorite game, too.

												So as someone who has never played Battlezone but is a huge fan of action-strategy games, you'd think this would've absolutely blown my mind. After about 2-3 hours, I'm not so sure. Don't get me wrong, I'm not saying it's bad, as far as a remaster goes, this is how it should be done... mod support, working multiplayer, ability to download new maps for instant action, graphical enhancements etc... this is a damn good remaster. I think my problem is truly just expectations. As someone who has heard about how amazing this game is and how it's pretty much the best action-strategy game to be released, all I can do is compare it to Uprising: Join or Die and how different philosophies they both are. Battlezone is slower, controls are floaty (because low gravity and hover tanks), units can be controlled directly and vehicles are all interchangeable with the player. You've also got 2 resources, scrap (metals) and pilots (nonrenewable). Scrap is gathered by scavengers from deposits all over the map and blowing up enemy units (or your own) creates scrap that can be scavenged and reused. Pilots are a nonrenewable resource, you need one for every unit you build. If the unit blows up, the pilot is ejected but he can also be killed thus losing him for good. If he makes it back to base, then your limit is not affected. It should also be noted that units have multiple weapon types and it doesn't seem like anyone is overly good against anyone else. Seems like numbers win the day in battles (from what I've played so far). This game also punishes you for your stupid teammates and makes you feel like you're just another soldier except you call in units.Uprising: Join or Die on the other hand is more arcadey. It's fast-paced and operates more on a paper rock scissors format. Infantry beats building, Tank beats Infantry, Aircraft beats Bomber and Tanks, Bomber beats building, Building good against everything etc etc. It's more simplistic. Units cannot be directly controlled, they are called in and proceed to battle against any enemy within the area but after the battle can be recalled to gain back resources. Your tank is also your ultimate weapon, it can be upgraded with better weaponry and by the end of the game you'll be blasting away foes with about 12 different weapon types.  Your tank can also divert power to 3 areas, shields, weaponry or speed... making you take more damage, deal more damage or zip around the battlefield at ridiculous speeds. Buildings are called in on pads rather than you essentially placing them whether you want (except for turrets). It should also be mentioned that Uprising is brutally hard, but not because your allies are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥... rather you made a mistake and they capitalized on it. I could go on but I believe my point is clear.Here we have two different action-strategy games that took the genre and walked opposite ways with it yet still remained true to a couple of different concepts (like having a command tank). In summation, Battlezone 98 Redux is good for those who are looking for more of a slower paced, punishing game... Battlezone is your game. If you're looking for a twitch shooter that plays more like The Outfit, then Uprising: Join or Die is your game. I still believe this should be played by anyone who is a fan of action-strategy games!

												At last, the FPS-RTS hybrid from 1998 has made it to Steam, and with a fresh coat of paint! Play as the National Space Defense Force (Americans) or the Cosmo Communist Army (Russians) and wage war across many different worlds, including Luna (Earth's Moon), Mars, Venus, and many more!Take command of your forces from a first-person perspective. You will need to be able to issue orders and fight in your own tank at the same time. This gameplay style is the adrenaline rush that is Battlezone. Destroy your enemy's forces, then gather their biometal remains to produce more of your own. Gathering scrap is important.The gameplay has been left completely untouched, so those who have played Battlezone 1.5 will fit right in. However, with respect to the last official patch, which was 1.4, expect a completely new experience. For one, the Tank AI no longer retreats when shot, it actually fights properly. The infamous bugs from back in the day are no more! The MDM is now safe to use in multiplayer, The East-West bug is fixed, and having a framerate over 60 FPS no longer makes the game run faster. Battlezone is finally up to modern standards as of v1.5 and Battlezone 98 Redux! At the time of this review, there may still be a few kinks to iron out, but I'm sure the dev team is more than willing to issue patches as issues are found. At $20, this game is a steal.

IntroductionBattlezone 98 Redux is set in a alternative version of 1960s whereby the USA and Soviet Union have secretly deployed armies into space for an extra-terrestrial substance that can be forged to craft weapons and armour that is powerful. Obviously other Nations are going to fight over this substance, so the National Space Dfence Force and  Cosmos Colonist Army battle over control of this substance.GameplayThis game is a blend of RTS and FPS elements that really seem to fit together and join together as one rather well. With the game primarily taking place in space with a sort of futuristic style it really takes upon the genre rather well. You can play as a hover tank that you can view from the cockpit, hunting down enemys with the hovertank destorying enemy crafts is rather satifying and brings back memories of when I used to play Starwars battlefront II.Although the game looks rather nice and seems like a pretty strong build from the earlier version of the game, sometimes the AI on the game seems a bit unresponsive and just sits there. Sometimes their pathfinding of where they are actually suppose to be moving can be a bit weird and obserdly different than what you would expect them to do.Anyways, the game is a really good source of what a RTS game should be all about. Being able to deploy your recycler at a power source to collect bio-metal that are used in the base in order to build defensive structers and wingmen into the battle. You are able to build towers to help you in the battle, with things such as Comm Tower which can take control of a satellite and you are able to view the battlezone. This gives you the added advantage of being able to command your wingmen in the traditional wya that you would normally in other RTS games.With the graphics remasterd from the 1998 version of the game, it looks very nice and sharp which is what you would expect a game to look like in todays standards. With the hovercrafts and towers looking very futuristic and nicely detailed, I feel like the game was refinely detailed in every way when this game was being developed. The textures look very smooth and the explosions on are very nice.Pros+ Detailed graphics+ Fun gameplay+ Shows what a RTS should rally be like+ FPS in a RTS game is very unique and hard to come by on steamCons- Weird AI at timesResult / Final ThoughtsMy final thoughts on this game are pretty high. They really took the original game and made it into a modern version, with the graphics of everything and the amount of towers you can build to help you win the battle it really shows what you can do with a RTS game. If you can get past the weird AI at times, then I would definatly recommened this game.Rating: 8.2/10For more reviews on a wide range of games, go and follow KgX Gaming curator group here.

												Where do we begin...Battlezone 98 was a game far ahead of its time.  When first person shooters and strategy games were still in larval stages while platformers and other genres dominated the market, this game brilliantly blended the two bold new genres together in a format unlike any other.  Not only did you build buildings and commanded armies, you went on the frontlines with them with powerful tanks, and if you were feeling lucky, you can disembark one for REAL sniper skill challenges as a humble trooper.  They have a wonderful mix of both units, and arsenals that can shake the game up faster than a bartender on crack mixing a martini.The primary drawbacks i site on this is the lack of open ended skirmish both offline and online, if they did this like other strategy games did back in the day this game would be perfect, and resources are very finite making gameplay restrictive.  The game is very challenging but can be a real controller/mouse to the screen difficult, and not in the challenging way that uber gamers desire, more like, "WHY THE ♥♥♥♥!? HOW!?" where you can only have a margin in the lower single digits of error to proceed.The game had immense potential, and it still does, but as long as the gameplay remains this restrictive it won't go further than it is.  Despite the flaws, i still recommend this hidden gem to anyone seeking a witches brew of intense first person shooting combat and calculating real time strategy gameplay molded into one.  Cold War in space yo! Fight with alien tech mang!

												My favorite game apart from maybe Interstate '76, and it's based upon that game's engine anyway. One of the defining games of my childhood and well deserving of this re-release.Originally released in 1998, this take on Battlezone was itself a re-imagining of the 1980 arcade game. It blended first-person vehicular combat with real-time strategy elements to create a revolutionary hybrid game experience that has only been briefly revisited since, in games such as Sacrifice and Brutal Legend.In 1952, as the story goes, a meteor shower in the arctic circle brought a previously unknown organic material to Earth. Simultaneously discovered by scientists of both the US and the Soviet Union, this "Bio-Metal" was soon discovered to have the unique ability to remember shapes it had previously assumed. From this material, the superpowers created hovering tanks and weapons centuries ahead of anything they could have otherwise made at the time. They quickly ran out of it, and turned their eyes towards the stars in search of more. In secret, the two nations sent thousand-man armies into space. Thus began a new, hidden chapter of the Cold War- the one too brutal to televise. You will journey to the moon, Mars, Venus and beyond in search of the bio-metal, and the truth of its origins.You take the role of a soldier of either the Americans' National Space Defense Force, or NSDF, or the Russians' Cosmo Colonist Army, or CCA. You begin most campaign missions, as well as multiplayer strategy matches, with your own tank and a Recycler- at once your core base structure, your resource depository, and a factory that produces all other essential units. It exists in a mobile or deployed state, able to travel (slowly) about until you find a geyser over which to deploy it, whereupon it becomes able to build. You have two resources: scrap, and pilots. The former are gathered by scavengers, autonomous resource-harvesting vehicles built from the Recycler that will wander the map gathering bio-metal scrap, found lying around in fields on most maps, or generated from destroyed vehicles and structures. Controlling these scrap fields and assigning escorts to your scavengers is crucial in more difficult missions, and in multiplayer.Combat vehicles include nimble scout craft, light and medium tanks, rocket tanks, bombers, and walkers. Defensive units include mobile turrets and artillery that must deploy to fire, as well as minelayers. Offensive vehicles for the most part are fast, turn quickly and can strafe, allowing you to maintain fire on a target while avoiding return fire, though the bombers do not turn quickly and are more adept at long-range strikes on static structures. Combat is fast and chaotic- focused fire can destroy most vehicles in seconds, and battles can involve upwards of twenty tanks at once- more in the campaign. You should quickly master the ability to group your units using Control plus the Function keys, and commanding them to focus-fire individual enemy targets, lest they haphazardly engage multiple enemies at once and lose the advantage of their numbers. The scouts and turrets are built from your Recycler, while the rest are built from your Unit Factory, a more specialized builder vehicle that is also built from the Recycler. If a vehicle is destroyed, including yours, fear not- the pilot will eject, and have the opportunity to return to their base and be put in a new vehicle. While on foot, you are extremely vulnerable, but not defenseless- you have a low-damage plasma gun, as well as a sniper rifle you can use to snipe out the pilot of an enemy vehicle and steal it for yourself. Be wary of enemy pilots in multiplayer!You may also build a Constructor vehicle from your Recycler that can build fixed structures, such as powerful gun towers, repair and resupply structures, and a communications tower that grants you access to an overhead satellite view in the vein of a traditional RTS. It can also build a barracks- the only way to increase your pilot count. Protect your Constructor well- it's often a priority target for AI enemies, and getting a network of gun towers up is crucial for fending off regular enemy raids in the later campaign missions. You will also want to build an Armory, a third mobile base vehicle that builds and launches repair, ammo and weapon pickups, as it is your only means of repairing structures and allows you to resupply in the field, as well as launch bombs on enemy bases.You can command your units either by looking directly at them and pressing the space bar or by selecting them using the number keys from a list. Units are organized into offensive, defensive, utility, with an extra section for available navigation beacons, which also function as cameras when selected, to give you remote viewing of that location. Offensive units have the most diverse range of orders- they can be commanded to move to a specific location, attack or defend your current target, follow you, defend a key friendly, or to move to a selected nav beacon, as well as to get repairs or ammunition, or to recycle- refunding a portion of scrap used in their construction, as well as returning their pilots to your global pilot count- this is good, because you have a finite cap of 30 pilots per level and they cannot be replaced. This works both ways- target enemy pilots to deny the AI access to replacement units- I think. The computer probably cheats on both scrap and pilots, and they most certainly can spawn near-infinite waves of harassing attacks on your base. It works in multiplayer though.Aside from the two story campaigns, there are a variety of multiplayer modes, including deathmatch, strategy, and "MPI", a form of co-op strategy versus AI. This Redux includes extensive Steam Workshop support- you can download maps on the fly even in-game. It also includes updated models and visual effects, trading cards, achievements, and other niceties- aside from running very smoothly on modern systems, more so then it ever did in the old days. However, it is a essentially a straight re-release, and does not attempt to address any of the game's existing shortcomings- save the netcode, of course.You are limited, for example, to only ten units of each type, since that's as far as the number keys go, as well as the hard pilot cap of 30. The AI is single-minded at best and suicidal at worst, with frequent issues with pathfinding, often getting stuck trying to scale inclines the player would have no trouble at all with. Scavengers are completely incapable of not only defending themselves but even of reacting to being attacked, and will continue on their merry way scavenging in the face of certain destruction. Artillery units will fire at will regardless of the risk of hitting your own forces and cannot be set to hold their fire. Your offensive units also require careful management ot get the most out of their attacks. The walkers are also so painfully slow that their use in most campaign missions is extremely limited- its entirely possible to finish CCA Mission 6, for example, without the use of the three Golems you are given. Most campaign missions also have only one or two safe methods of completion, with very little room for experimental tactics.However, most of these flaws are attributable to the limitations of the original game engine, and and while they are even more glaringly obvious all these years later, there is something to be said for bringing the game to Steam and a new audience as is, the way we enjoyed it 18 years ago, and it is certainly easier to forgive then a brand new game with these same flaws. Battlezone was something completely new and any problems it had were excusable in the face of how much fun I had with it, and it was a great pleasure to revisit this landmark title in both my young life and the history of PC gaming. I urge newcomers and old hands, shooter and strategy fans alike to pick this one up. You will not be disappointed.

												What an amazing game.  I played the original version for 300+ hours. If you've played this before, then you already know how incredible it is and have bought it.If you haven't, this version of Battlezone is a hybrid FPS/RTS sci-fi tank/battle Cold War simulator... in space. It's every bit as awesome as it sounds. Basically, imagine a really excellent, top-notch RTS with a fantastic interface in which you get to play as one of your own units while directing the battle. It sounds complex, but the UI is so excellent that neither part of the game, the tank simulator or the RTS, loses anything in the translation; it's two first-rate games in one. You play as a pilot who can switch ships and even snipe enemy pilots and take over their vehicles.I still remember the amazing adventures I had playing this game. The heart-pounding race to escape  a planet about to explode in seconds, being chased by alien superweapons all the way. Escorting my Soviet scientists across a bridge above the fiery lava of Jupiter's moon Io, getting blown out of my tank as it's destroyed by superior American forces, sniping the pilot of an American rocket tank who attacked me, stealing his vehicle and using it to fire upon my unsuspcecting foes, saving my forces. Sneaking into a heavily defended Soviet base on Europa to see where they've hdiden the stolen plans. Being ambushed by Soviet forces on the plains of Venus. They simply don't get any better than this.The emergent gameplay situations, the enormous tactical flexibility afforded by the strategic layer of the game, the first-rate physics and satisfying gunplay, the huge variety of weapons and vehicles- even nearly 20 years later, this game remains unmatched I truly wish more people would try to rip it off! To try to compare it to some more modern titles if you haven't played this, imagine melding the seamless tactical interface and large-scale battle control of Sins of a Solar Empire with the visceral action and FPS excitement of Call of Duty, plus the open-ended battlefield and branching combat options afforded by Crysis or Far Cry. All with a cool sci-fi story in space. I am not exaggerating. It truly is that good.And all this before I even get to the beautiful, loving restoration this game has been given!All of the above refers to the 1998 "vanilla" edition. But in this 98 Redux edition, the game has been given a complete makeover and beautifully brought up to date with care and devotion. The developers really layered on an extra level of polish along with all-new graphics and options for modern PCs. New, Steam-based online multiplayer? Check. Brand new HD graphics and textures? Check? New mod support? Check. In my brief time to date with the new version, AI also feels like it's been improved and bugs have been fixed. It really feels like a whole new game with the excellent graphics update. This is NOT the shovelware, throw-anything-on-Steam junk that most developers throw up onto the Internet when they get an old license- this is the remastered, restored edition, presented with the care and attention that all developers should lavish on a game rerelease. It truly is worth a buy even if you've played this as many hours as I have.Until then... I'll see you on the Martian battlefields... or the Moon.... or Venus....

Battlezone 98 Redux is a rehash of an old classic from 1998, brought to STEAM by Rebellion, a company behind such titles as Sniper Elite or Aliens versus Predator [1999, 2010].Battlezone is a hybrid style game, a crossover between first person view vehicle combat shooter [FPS for short] and a real time strategy [RTS]. Does that mix do the job? Yes and no. What is certainly lacking is a pause-and-command button, minding the FPS element is often intense, leaving very little time to make grand strategic decisions. But whether playing Command and Conquer you have ever thought if it was you in one of those tanks, you'd show'em, here you go, Battlezone is all about that and it is tough as nails.The game is a true classic, reminding me of UFO Enemy Unknown [1993] in many aspects. Battlezone and UFO are both innovative, experimenting and focused on multilayer management. Both also represent core science-fiction. While UFO is yet turn-based and more general, Battlezone is real-time and down to the gunbattle.Battlezone is definitely a gem of its time, probably even beyond its time, probably even beyond any time before or after its release, so to say. It is just a unique product. How does it stand nowadays? How playable it ultimately is at the present?That is when things come down to the rating, which unfortunately is negative. STEAM review must be either recommending or dissuading. With greatest difficulty I see this game appealing to modern [2016] players. The problem is more than just nature of visuals or lacking of certain ease elements, such as the mentioned pause-and-command function. It is the oftentimes chaotic picture of action, difficulty of FPS combat and movement controls, overall difficulty level, complex real-time base and force management with flaws characteristic to the early productions standing for RTS genre.The score is 5/10 wHATs grade. I should best repeat what has already been put in one of the other customers reviews: if you are prone to like this game, you probably already know it, thus have little need for any reviews to help you make up your mind about the purchase. Otherwise, if you hesitate, skip it.What is needed with Battlezone, is a complete remake [reboot], reintroducing the game to the modern public, instead of only a visual facelift [redux]. Currently it is a niche release, addressed towards the original versions veterans.

												Battlezone was released back in 1998 and was one of the first action-RTS hybrids - it has all the usual elements of an RTS, but you command from the ground in a vehicle, fighting alongside your troops. The genre never really took off, but because Battlezone was bundled with a lot of graphics cards it reached a wide audience and gained a cult following.If you are someone who's considering buying this having played it way back when, do it. It's a reworking, not a remake, so the real BZ atmosphere is still there. The ships and buildings are all heavily redone, with much more detailed models and much larger textures. They look excellent. The terrain looks very much like it did back in the original, so it's still behind Battlezone 2, nevermind more modern titles. But all things considered, the graphics do a good job today with the update. The gameplay is as rich as ever. Multiplayer is now handled through Steam within the game, which keeps things nice and simple, with all the old options. A bomber DM is still a thrill after all these years.If you are someone who's never played the original and are wondering whether you should buy this, well don't expect it to look fresh. The developers of this update have done an incredible job hauling parts of the game into the 2010s, but there are engine limitations. Firefights are limited to a few hundred meters in distance, and don't expect detailed ballistics or other physics.The real joy of Battlezone, however, was always its gameplay, and its blend of FPS and RTS that has never really been replicated since. In each mission you will be dogfighting and base building, often at the same time. A selection of ships can be built, each of which offer different benefits, and you can kit them out with a variety of weapons. Your resources ("biometal") are gathered by Scavengers which have an annoying habit of wandering off into dangerous areas and so need to be constantly protected. Two single-player campaigns are included, so there's a hefty chunk of content for someone who has no plans to dabble in multiplayer.At the price, this game still delivers eighteen years after its original release, whether you're looking for something new or a satisfying hit of nostalgia. Buy it.
